title: About Me

content:
For a long time, I wanted a simple place on the internet where I could write about tech, document small wins, share problems I solve, or even drop personal thoughts. Not a fancy platform, not something overloaded with features â€” just a clean space where I could write my way, at my pace.
And todayâ€¦ you’re reading this on blog.krish2005.tech â€” my new home on the web.
This is the story of how it came together.
ğŸ§  My Mindset: Keep It Simple, But Developer-Friendly I knew I wanted a few things right from the start:
Minimal setup â€” because I don’t want to spend weeks installing plugins. Fast & lightweight â€” no bloat, no unnecessary JS. Markdown-based â€” writing should feel natural. Free hosting â€” because why pay for something simple? Customizable later as I grow â€” I’m a developer; I will tweak things. Basically:
I wanted something like Medium’s simplicity, but with GitHub-level control.
ğŸ” Options I Considered Before jumping in, I looked at several options:
1. Write.as / BearBlog They were beautifully minimal â€” but I eventually realized I’d want more customization.
2. Substack / Medium Great writing experience, but:
No full control No real customization Poor for dev-heavy posts Hard to design my own structure later 3. Blogger / WordPress.com These felt too old-school or too bloated.
4. Static site generators like: Hugo Jekyll Astro 11ty These gave full control but required some setup â€” still worth it.
ğŸš€ Why I Chose Hugo + Cloudflare Pages This stack won for a few reasons:
âœ” Crazy fast builds (Hugo compiles instantly) âœ” Markdown content âœ” Free static hosting with Cloudflare Pages âœ” Automatic HTTPS âœ” Git-based workflow âœ” Easy custom domain âœ” Future customization is limitless And the PaperMod theme made the whole site look clean and modern with almost zero effort.
So the decision was made:
Hugo for content â†’ Cloudflare Pages for hosting.
ğŸ§± The Actual Steps I Took (So You Can Do It Too) Here’s exactly how I did it:
1. Install Hugo On Windows:
choco install hugo Check:
hugo version 2. Create a new Hugo site hugo new site Blog cd Blog 3. Add PaperMod theme git init git submodule add https://github.com/adityatelange/hugo-PaperMod.git themes/PaperMod Edit hugo.toml to include:
theme = "PaperMod" 4. Create first pages Homepage content, About page, and first post.
Example:
hugo new posts/hello-world.md I edited them later to add proper text.
5. Preview locally hugo server -D This was the moment where I finally saw my site.
6. Push to GitHub git add . git commit -m "Initial commit" git branch -M main git remote add origin <repo-url> git push -u origin main 7. Deploy to Cloudflare Pages This part was trickier.
At first, I accidentally created a Worker instead of a Pages project This resulted in Cloudflare ignoring Hugo entirely and showing only:
Hello world And later a 404 page.
I spent time debugging it until I realized:
ğŸ‘‰ I must use Pages, not Workers.
So I deleted the Worker and created a Pages â†’ Connect to Git project.
Inside Cloudflare Pages, I set:
Build command: hugo Output directory: public Env variable: HUGO_VERSION = 0.152.2 Then Cloudflare finally ran a real build.
8. Connecting my .tech domain When my domain became available, I added:
blog.krish2005.tech Cloudflare automatically configured DNS and HTTPS.
Seeing my site live on a real domain was so satisfying.
ğŸ§© Problems I Faced & How I Solved Them âŒ Problem 1 â€” Cloudflare kept showing “Hello world” This was because it was deploying as a Worker, not a Page.
Fix: Delete Worker â†’ Create Pages project.
âŒ Problem 2 â€” 404 after deployment This happened because Cloudflare deployed 0 files.
Fix: Ensure output directory = public And Hugo actually builds properly.
âŒ Problem 3 â€” Couldn’t change .pages.dev URL Turns out: Page subdomains are fixed. Solution: use my custom .tech domain instead.
ğŸ‰ What I Learned Static site generators are powerful once you get past the initial setup. Cloudflare Pages is one of the best free dev tools available today. A blog doesn’t have to be perfect â€” it just needs to exist. Writing is easier when you own your space. ğŸŒ± What’s next? I’ll be writing about:
Things I learn Projects I build Tech experiments Mistakes & debugging stories Personal growth This blog is not just a website â€” it’s a timeline of me becoming a better developer.
If you’ve read this far: Thanks for joining me on day one.
